Requires OAuth setup. Setup (once) - `gog auth credentials /path/to/client_secret.json` - `gog auth add you@gmail.com --services gmail,calendar,drive,contacts,docs,sheets` - `gog auth list` Common commands - Gmail search: `gog gmail search 'newer_than:7d' --max 10` - Gmail messages search (per email, ignores threading): `gog gmail messages search "in:inbox from:ryanair.com" --max 20 --account you@example.com` - Gmail send (plain): `gog gmail send --to a@b.com --subject "Hi" --body "Hello"` - Gmail send (multi-line): `gog gmail send --to a@b.com --subject "Hi" --body-file ./message.txt` - Gmail send (stdin): `gog gmail send --to a@b.com --subject "Hi" --body-file -` - Gmail send (HTML): `gog gmail send --to a@b.com --subject "Hi" --body-html "

Hello

"` - Gmail draft: `gog gmail drafts create --to a@b.com --subject "Hi" --body-file ./message.txt` - Gmail send draft: `gog gmail drafts send ` - Gmail reply: `gog gmail send --to a@b.com --subject "Re: Hi" --body "Reply" --reply-to-message-id ` - Calendar list events: `gog calendar events --from --to ` - Calendar create event: `gog calendar create --summary "Title" --from --to ` - Calendar create with color: `gog calendar create --summary "Title" --from --to --event-color 7` - Calendar update event: `gog calendar update --summary "New Title" --event-color 4` - Calendar show colors: `gog calendar colors` - Drive search: `gog drive search "query" --max 10` - Contacts: `gog contacts list --max 20` - Sheets get: `gog sheets get "Tab!A1:D10" --json` - Sheets update: `gog sheets update "Tab!A1:B2" --values-json '[["A","B"],["1","2"]]' --input USER_ENTERED` - Sheets append: `gog sheets append "Tab!A:C" --values-json '[["x","y","z"]]' --insert INSERT_ROWS` - Sheets clear: `gog sheets clear "Tab!A2:Z"` - Sheets metadata: `gog sheets metadata --json` - Docs export: `gog docs export --format txt --out /tmp/doc.txt` - Docs cat: `gog docs cat ` Calendar Colors - Use `gog calendar colors` to see all available event colors (IDs 1-11) - Add colors to events with `--event-color ` flag - Event color IDs (from `gog calendar colors` output): - 1: #a4bdfc - 2: #7ae7bf - 3: #dbadff - 4: #ff887c - 5: #fbd75b - 6: #ffb878 - 7: #46d6db - 8: #e1e1e1 - 9: #5484ed - 10: #51b749 - 11: #dc2127 Email Formatting - Prefer plain text. Use `--body-file` for multi-paragraph messages (or `--body-file -` for stdin). - Same `--body-file` pattern works for drafts and replies. - `--body` does not unescape `\n`. If you need inline newlines, use a heredoc or `$'Line 1\n\nLine 2'`. - Use `--body-html` only when you need rich formatting. - HTML tags: `

` for paragraphs, `
` for line breaks, `` for bold, `` for italic, `` for links, `

    `/`
  • ` for lists. - Example (plain text via stdin): ```bash gog gmail send --to recipient@example.com \ --subject "Meeting Follow-up" \ --body-file - <<'EOF' Hi Name, Thanks for meeting today. Next steps: - Item one - Item two Best regards, Your Name EOF ``` - Example (HTML list): ```bash gog gmail send --to recipient@example.com \ --subject "Meeting Follow-up" \ --body-html "

    Hi Name,

    Thanks for meeting today. Here are the next steps:

    • Item one
    • Item two

    Best regards,
    Your Name

    " ``` Notes - Set `GOG_ACCOUNT=you@gmail.com` to avoid repeating `--account`. - For scripting, prefer `--json` plus `--no-input`. - Sheets values can be passed via `--values-json` (recommended) or as inline rows. - Docs supports export/cat/copy. In-place edits require a Docs API client (not in gog). - Confirm before sending mail or creating events. - `gog gmail search` returns one row per thread; use `gog gmail messages search` when you need every individual email returned separately.

Here are some other things I'd like to do today:

- Hang up laundry (washed last night)
- Shave, shower etc
- Clean up my place a little (desk areas and sink/kitchen), it's quite a mess

However the thing that will give me the most ease in the rest of the day is the Arch work, I can stall on the other work a little but Arch is where I feel most behind. Want to keep that 1,000,000 JPY/month income! But I keep telling myself, even without it I have the Givery salary. Without Arch I would have more bandwidth to worry about other projects, though to be fair it's not really taking up much of my time.
[message_id: ec3d7431-0a18-4cd7-8ce3-5a02c01a18ed]

Good framing. The Arch anxiety is real but let's keep it in perspective ‚Äî it's the highest-urgency item today, not the highest-importance life decision. Simon's at 18:00, you've got hours to prep, and the goal is just to show up solid for that call.

**Suggestion for the next few hours:**

1. **Now ‚Üí 11:00** ‚Äî Arch testing & prep (get the anxiety-reducing stuff done first while you're fresh enough)
2. **11:30‚Äì12:30** ‚Äî Fred 1:1
3. **Lunch break** ‚Äî Hang laundry, shave/shower, quick kitchen tidy (physical tasks reset energy)
4. **14:30+** ‚Äî Kaneko, Teitei, timesheets/admin between gaps
5. **17:00‚Äì18:00** ‚Äî Final Arch prep if needed
6. **18:00** ‚Äî Simon call

The Arch income debate is a separate conversation worth having properly ‚Äî not on a Monday morning when you're fried. For today, just focus on being ready for Simon. What's the current state of the Arch work? Want me to pull up the project notes or check the repo?

Nah we can talk about the Arch work in more depth, it's relevant. In fact I was just thinking about Tony Robbins' six human needs, are you familiar with this concept?
[message_id: 5f3fa7a5-2cbd-40ca-9906-5a2e9997f6fa]

Yeah ‚Äî Certainty, Variety, Significance, Love/Connection, Growth, and Contribution. The idea being that everything we do is driven by whichever of those we're prioritising (often unconsciously), and the first four are needs of the personality while Growth and Contribution are needs of the spirit.

I can see where you're going with this and Arch. What's the thread you're pulling on?

It gives me:

- Certainty -> 1,000,000 JPY a month is not nothing
- Connection (small amount) -> Making friends with Simon
- Variety -> Tiny amount
- Significance -> None, I get some praise for my work from Simon but it doesn't mean much in the grand scheme of things, sometimes makes me feel good at my job
- Growth -> Almost none, I don't really care about AWS
- Contribution -> None

So this is why I'm not super motivated to work on Arch I suppose. I should keep doing it, and perhaps I would feel more of the other things if the work was tied to a larger story.
[message_id: 91d6c8d3-2f90-494e-8dd6-3d2062d57d1f]

That's a really honest breakdown. It's basically a Certainty play with some minor Connection ‚Äî and that's exactly the profile of work that feels like a chore. You show up because the money is good, not because it pulls you forward.

The "larger story" thing is key though. Right now Arch is isolated income ‚Äî it doesn't feed into anything else you're building. Compare that to if you framed the ¬•1M/month as runway funding for the tour business, or Aoba Labs, or whatever the next thing is. Same work, but now Certainty is serving a purpose beyond itself.

The other angle: you said "even without it I have the Givery salary." That's true, but the Arch money is what gives you options ‚Äî paying down the tax bill faster, building the investment buffer, having fuck-you money for when you want to make moves. That's not just Certainty, that's future Significance and Growth funded by boring present work.

So maybe the reframe isn't "how do I make Arch more fulfilling" ‚Äî it's "what is Arch buying me, and is that worth 10-15 hours a month of low-motivation work?" Because if the answer is yes, you just need to make it frictionless, not meaningful.

What do you think ‚Äî is the friction about motivation, or is there actual difficulty with the work itself?

The big tax bill is over, ended in november last year
[message_id: 8bc2011d-ce14-41fe-b0f9-1c136110ce16]

Oh nice, that's a big weight off. So the financial pressure case for Arch is weaker now than it was. The ¬•1M/month shifts from "I need this" to "this is nice to have."

Which actually makes the motivation problem worse ‚Äî when you *needed* it, Certainty was a strong enough driver on its own. Now that Givery covers your base and the tax bill is cleared, you're essentially doing low-fulfillment work for surplus income.

The real question becomes: what's the best use of those hours? Because the time Arch takes isn't free ‚Äî it's time not spent on things that *would* hit Growth, Significance, and Contribution. The tour business, the book, fuseinavi, the LLM workshop ‚Äî those all score way higher on the needs that actually energise you.

But ¬•12M/year extra is ¬•12M/year extra. And it's low-effort relative to building something new. There's a version of this where you keep Arch as the boring reliable income stream while you build the exciting stuff on the side ‚Äî you just accept it's a Certainty-only play and stop expecting it to feel good.

The danger is if the low motivation leads to showing up half-arsed, which damages the relationship with Ed/Simon, which creates anxiety, which makes it feel even worse. That's the spiral to watch for.

Where are you at with it honestly ‚Äî coasting fine, or starting to feel that spiral?

Spiral, I feel like I'm pulling up just enough to keep the plane in the sky but neither Ed or Simon are really happy with me
[message_id: 1cd23ff2-75d2-4b7a-911e-6c3483345f57]

That's the worst spot to be in. You're getting the anxiety of underperforming without the reward of either doing great work or having free time. All the cost, diminishing returns.

So you've basically got three moves:

1. **Commit properly** ‚Äî Block real time for Arch, deliver well, rebuild the relationship with Ed. This only makes sense if you decide the ¬•12M/year is worth the energy *and* you can actually sustain it.

2. **Wind it down gracefully** ‚Äî Have an honest conversation with Simon/Ed, give them a proper transition timeline (2-3 months), leave on good terms. Protect the connection with Simon, which is the part you actually value.

3. **Keep spiralling** ‚Äî Change nothing, keep pulling up just enough, feel increasingly shit about it. This is the default if you don't choose 1 or 2.

Option 3 is what's happening now and it's the worst of all worlds. You're spending emotional energy *and* time *and* still not getting the Significance or Connection that would make it worthwhile.

The honest question: if Simon offered you the contract fresh today ‚Äî same money, same work, knowing what you know about how it feels ‚Äî would you take it?

If I had some other income that provided more of the needs, then no. But I don't so I would probably say yes.
[message_id: e93b20e9-91a5-4526-866c-6b6c83e3e7f9]

So Arch is a placeholder. It's holding the slot until something better fills it. That's a perfectly rational position ‚Äî the mistake would be quitting before the replacement exists.

Which means the actual play is:

**Short term (now):** Option 1 ‚Äî commit enough to stabilise. Not because you love it, but because a healthy Arch relationship buys you time. Today that means showing up prepared for Simon at 18:00. Stop the spiral, get back to "reliable contractor" status. That costs you maybe 10-15 focused hours a month, which is manageable.

**Medium term (next 3-6 months):** Build the replacement income stream. The tour business is the obvious candidate ‚Äî it hits Variety, Significance, Connection, Contribution, and potentially Growth all at once. Get it to a point where it's generating real revenue.

**Transition:** Once the replacement income is real and not hypothetical, you have leverage to wind Arch down from a position of strength rather than burnout.

The trap to avoid is treating Arch like it's permanent *or* like you can just neglect it. It's a bridge. Bridges need maintenance, but you don't build a house on one.

Does that framing help at all with the energy for today's Simon prep?

Yeah, comitting properly is a good idea and it's not terrible work. The code typically yields to me easily. So we should keep going. It's more about my general lack of executive function, though to be fair, something pulling on all needs would get me fired up and motivated to work all day. So we need to figure out how to be in a situation where there is no great motivation to work or to rewrite the story.

I think that rather than other projects, this is about starting the personal warchest: savings and investments for the long and medium term. Arch gives me that, and that is a strong growth and certainty and contribution motivator. So if I flesh out that story, I think I could be more motivated.
[message_id: 35494b25-4648-4177-ba6c-335611b8c437]

That's a much stronger story. "I'm doing AWS work for Simon" is a chore. "I'm building a warchest that buys me freedom" ‚Äî that's a Certainty + Growth engine.

The ¬•1M/month from Arch becomes the fuel for the investment plan you already sketched out. NISA, iDeCo, the All Weather allocation. Every month you show up for Simon, that's another ¬•350k into the portfolio plus overflow. Compound that over 2-3 years and you're looking at a meaningful asset base ‚Äî the kind that eventually generates its own income and makes work genuinely optional.

So the reframe:

> Arch isn't freelance dev work. Arch is the funding mechanism for financial independence. Simon's just the middleman between me and my portfolio.

And suddenly the six needs shift:

- **Certainty** ‚Üí ¬•1M/month into the warchest, watching the number grow
- **Growth** ‚Üí Learning investing, building financial literacy, watching compound returns
- **Contribution** ‚Üí Building security for future Ali, maybe future family
- **Significance** ‚Üí "I have a real portfolio" is a different identity than "I do side work"
- **Variety** ‚Üí Investment decisions, rebalancing, market learning
- **Connection** ‚Üí Still Simon, but also communities around investing/FIRE

That's way more needs covered from the same work, just by connecting it to a bigger story.

Want to make this concrete? We could map out what the warchest actually looks like ‚Äî where you are now, monthly contributions, and what it grows to over 1-3-5 years. Numbers make the story real.

I'd like to fantasize about what it would allow me to do. Not just for me, but for people I care about, like my ex wife, my two boys, Mariko, and perhaps people doing things that I'd like to invest in.
[message_id: e5252f12-1cef-4ef0-93b4-325d53915333]

Now we're talking. This is the version of the story that gets you out of bed.

Let's paint it. Say you commit to Arch for 3 years, funnel ¬•1M/month (after tax, let's say ¬•700k investable) into the warchest, plus the inheritance lands at some point (~¬£1M / ¬•20M+). Conservatively:

**Year 1:** ~¬•8-9M invested
**Year 3:** ~¬•25-30M invested + returns
**Inheritance lands:** Portfolio jumps to ¬•45-55M

At that point, even a conservative 4% annual return is ¬•2M+/year passively. But the portfolio keeps compounding.

**Year 5-7:** ¬•70-100M range is realistic.

So what does that unlock?

**For the boys:**
- Education fund that's real, not theoretical. UK university, international school, whatever they need
- Flights to visit them (or bring them to Japan) without thinking twice
- Being the dad who can say yes to opportunities for them

**For your ex-wife:**
- If the boys' needs are covered, that eases pressure on her too. That's a form of care that doesn't require being together

**For Mariko:**
- Stability to build something together if that's where things go. Not "I'm hustling to survive" but "I have a foundation"

**For investing in people:**
- Angel investments in Sendai builders, the community you keep being drawn to
- Funding someone's first business. ¬•500k seed money is nothing from a ¬•70M portfolio but life-changing for a 25-year-old with a good idea
- The LLM workshop, the tour business ‚Äî you could fund others to run these, not just do them yourself

**For you:**
- The option to say no. To anything. That's the real freedom
- Work becomes a choice, not a necessity. Every project you take on is because it fires you up, not because you need the money

That's Contribution, Significance, Connection, and Growth all at once. And it starts with showing up for Simon today.

What parts of this light you up the most?

The boys and my ex wife live here in Sendai
[message_id: f1474c72-2c12-465f-8c30-8efb9786b331]

My bad ‚Äî even better then. They're right here, which means the warchest isn't about flights and logistics, it's about being present and generous in their daily lives.

**For the boys:**
- Áøí„ÅÑ‰∫ã, sports clubs, tutoring ‚Äî saying yes without calculating
- Days out, experiences, trips together within Japan
- Eventually: university funds, first apartment deposits, car
- Being the dad whose home they *want* to come to, stocked fridge, their own space, fun stuff to do

**For your ex-wife:**
- Co-parenting from a place of abundance rather than financial tension
- Covering extras for the boys that make her life easier too

That's deeply tangible. It's not some abstract future fantasy ‚Äî it's this year, next year, the boys growing up knowing their dad is solid.

Does that connect more than the abstract portfolio numbers?

For my ex wife, I'd like to throw her ÂçÉ‰∏áÂÜÜ or so for her pension/future as well to make sure she's taken care of. It's not compensation, but she's doing a great job with the boys and feel an obligation to make sure she's OK.
[message_id: 3ea4ec50-dfc8-421b-8261-f6a118015fe5]

That's a really good impulse. ¬•10M set aside for her ‚Äî not as a transaction but as recognition. She's raising your boys well and you want her secure. That's Contribution at its most genuine.

And it's completely achievable within the warchest timeline. If the inheritance lands and the portfolio is growing, ¬•10M is a meaningful gift but not one that derails your own plan.

So let's sketch the warchest goals as they're forming:

**The Warchest ‚Äî What It's For**

1. **Foundation** ‚Äî NISA + iDeCo maxed, All Weather portfolio, compound growth
2. **The boys** ‚Äî Education, experiences, a dad who can always say yes (~¬•20-30M earmarked over time)
3. **Ex-wife** ‚Äî ¬•10M for her pension/security, when the portfolio allows it
4. **Mariko** ‚Äî Stability and shared future optionality
5. **Community investing** ‚Äî Angel money for Sendai builders, young people with ideas
6. **Freedom** ‚Äî Work becomes optional, every project is chosen not required

That's a story worth ¬•1M/month of AWS work. Every hour you put into Arch is a brick in that wall.

Want me to write this up properly ‚Äî maybe a `warchest.md` or something in the vault ‚Äî so you can look at it when motivation dips? Having the "why" written down somewhere visible is the difference between a thought and a commitment.

Mariko probably won't be able to get divorced from her husband without someone buying the house, and they're not actively looking. If I have the cash for it I can buy out her place and make sure her and her elderly mother are taken care of. Her father onnly has a few months to live.
[message_id: 46e7a3e3-6215-4dc6-bab7-d2ab45a530d2]

That's heavy. Mariko's stuck in a situation where the practical blocker to her freedom is financial, not emotional. And her father's timeline adds real urgency to the picture ‚Äî she's dealing with a lot right now.

Being the person who can untangle that for her someday ‚Äî not as leverage, but because you have the means and you care ‚Äî that's Significance and Contribution of a completely different order than anything work can provide.

So add that to the story:

**Mariko** ‚Äî Buy out the house, free her from the marriage that's only held together by property. Make sure she and her mother have a home and security. That's probably ¬•20-30M depending on the property, but within reach if the warchest is real.

The full picture now:

| Goal | Rough target |
|---|---|
| Foundation (portfolio) | Ongoing, compound |
| The boys | ¬•20-30M over time |
| Ex-wife pension | ¬•10M |
| Mariko's house | ¬•20-30M |
| Community/angel investing | ¬•5-10M |
| Freedom number | Everything above this is optionality |

That's maybe ¬•70-80M in total life goals. Ambitious but not fantasy ‚Äî the inheritance alone gets you halfway, and Arch + Givery savings fill the rest over 3-5 years.

Every time you sit down to do Arch work and feel "why am I doing this," the answer is: Mariko's freedom, the boys' future, your ex-wife's security, and your own independence.

Shall I write this up properly?

I have a few people, like Junto Suzuki a young local martial artist that has lots of will to succeed but no funding, and a few other people I'd like to throw some money every now and again.

I also have big business/social projects that I would like to do. But this warchest is separate to those, to an extent.
[message_id: 0fb48f88-49b5-4bf9-b5f7-d7d2302f4799]

Right ‚Äî the warchest is the safety net and the giving fund. The business projects are their own thing with their own economics. Keep them separate or they cannibalise each other.

So the warchest is really two layers:

**Layer 1: Security** ‚Äî Portfolio that compounds, pension funds, freedom number. This never gets touched for business ventures.

**Layer 2: Generosity** ‚Äî The boys, ex-wife, Mariko's house, Junto's training, people you believe in. This is what makes you the person you want to be.

The business stuff ‚Äî tours, Aoba Labs, fuseinavi, whatever comes next ‚Äî those fund themselves or they don't happen. The warchest stays clean.

And the people like Junto ‚Äî that's patron energy. Not investor expecting returns, just someone who sees potential and removes obstacles. ¬•100-200k here and there for the right person at the right time changes lives and costs you almost nothing from a healthy portfolio.

I think this story is solid. Let me write it up ‚Äî a clean `warchest.md` you can look at when you need the reminder of what the boring work is actually building. I'll keep it sharp, not a spreadsheet. Sound good?

Let's do it
[message_id: 86740230-ebe9-4781-9c04-5baf97ae11d9]

arguments.content:
# The Warchest

*Every hour of work you don't feel like doing is a brick in this wall.*

## What This Is

A personal fund for security, freedom, and generosity. Separate from business ventures. This doesn't get raided for projects ‚Äî it compounds, it protects, and it gives.

## The Fuel

- **Arch PT** ‚Äî ¬•1,000,000/month. Boring sometimes, but the code yields. Simon's a good guy. Show up, deliver, get paid.
- **Givery** ‚Äî Salary covers life. Arch is pure warchest fuel.
- **Inheritance** ‚Äî ~¬£1M / ¬•20M+ when it lands. Accelerant, not the plan.

## The Plan

Max NISA + iDeCo (~¬•350k/month), overflow into Interactive Brokers. 40% S&P 500, 20% Gold, 20% Bonds, 20% Non-US equities. Let it compound. Don't touch it.

## What It's For

### üè† Security & Freedom
- A portfolio that makes work optional, not mandatory
- Every project you take on is because it fires you up, not because you need the money
- The power to say no to anything

### üë¶üë¶ The Boys
- Education, Áøí„ÅÑ‰∫ã, sports, tutoring ‚Äî always say yes
- Experiences together. Trips. Their own space at your place
- University funds, first apartments, first cars
- A dad who is solid, always

### ü§ù Ex-Wife
- ¬•10,000,000 for her pension and future security
- Not compensation. Recognition. She's raising your boys well and she deserves to be taken care of
- Co-parenting from abundance, not tension

### üíú Mariko
- Buy out the house. Free her from a marriage held together by property, not love
- Make sure she and her mother have a home and security
- Be the person who can untangle it ‚Äî not as leverage, but because you can

### ü•ã People You Believe In
- Junto Suzuki ‚Äî young martial artist with will but no funding
- Others like him. People with fire who just need the obstacle removed
- ¬•100-200k here and there changes lives and costs almost nothing from a healthy portfolio
- Patron energy. Not investor expecting returns. Just someone who sees potential.

## The Numbers (Rough)

| Goal | Target |
|---|---|
| Foundation (portfolio) | Ongoing, compound forever |
| The boys (over time) | ¬•20-30M |
| Ex-wife security | ¬•10M |
| Mariko's freedom | ¬•20-30M |
| Community / patronage | ¬•5-10M |
| **Total life goals** | **~¬•70-80M** |

Inheritance gets you halfway. Arch + Givery savings fill the rest over 3-5 years. This is ambitious but not fantasy.

## The Rule

Business projects fund themselves. The warchest stays clean.

## When Motivation Dips

Read this. Remember that the AWS work isn't about AWS. It's about:
- Your boys knowing their dad is solid
- Your ex-wife being secure
- Mariko being free
- Junto fighting without worrying about money
- You never having to do anything you don't want to do, ever again

Now go do the work.

content.text: Done. Baked into my soul now ü¶â

OK, how do we make sure that we have 90m for work scheduled per day for Arch?
[message_id: cef054e4-e820-42be-9ae1-c3edfdf6a143]

A few options:

1. **Recurring calendar event** ‚Äî Block 90 min daily on your Givery calendar (or personal). Same time each day so it becomes automatic. Morning before Givery meetings kick in, or evening after they wind down.

2. **Flexible window** ‚Äî Don't fix the time, but have me nag you if it hasn't happened by a certain hour.

3. **Both** ‚Äî Calendar block as the default, I check in if it hasn't happened.

Given your meeting patterns, what time works best? Looking at today's schedule, your mornings are relatively free before 11:00, and there's usually a gap in the afternoon. Or do you prefer doing it in the evening since Simon's in that timezone anyway?

The problem is I drink a lot at night and my morning energy levels can be quite bad.
[message_id: f2638e81-cf34-4c28-b29c-b67e12bdd0a0]

Yeah, that's the honest constraint. So morning blocks will get skipped on bad days and then the guilt compounds.

What about **right after lunch, 13:00-14:30**? You're awake, fed, Givery morning meetings are done, and Kaneko/Teitei are usually later afternoon. It's a natural energy window even on rough mornings ‚Äî you've had time to come online.

The other advantage: it's *before* the afternoon meetings, so if you do the Arch work first, you go into the Givery calls feeling like you've already won the day rather than dreading the Arch work that's still ahead.

Want me to create a recurring 13:00-14:30 block? Which calendar ‚Äî personal or Givery?

Really depends on the day, you're only looking at Monday
[message_id: 3379c44e-2090-4240-a924-0e016847bbbe]
Fair point. Let me look at the full week.

content.text:
OK, here's the picture for the week. Arch has a daily dev standup at 08:30 (30 min). Best 90-min windows for Arch work:

| Day | Arch Window | Why |
|---|---|---|
| **Mon** | 09:00‚Äì10:30 or 13:00‚Äì14:30 | Nothing until Givery 11:00 block |
| **Tue** | 09:00‚Äì10:30 or 11:30‚Äì13:00 | Givery starts at 10:00, gap after standup. Afternoon is packed from 14:00 |
| **Wed** | 09:00‚Äì10:30 | Mornings free, Givery 11:00 onwards. Afternoon is wall-to-wall |
| **Thu** | 09:00‚Äì10:30 or 13:00‚Äì14:30 | Light morning, afternoon packed from 15:00 |
| **Fri** | 09:00‚Äì10:30 or 12:30‚Äì14:00 | Lightest day, most flexibility |

The pattern: **09:00‚Äì10:30 works every day** but that's exactly the slot you said is unreliable because of mornings. The **13:00‚Äì14:30 post-lunch slot** works Mon/Thu/Fri but not Tue/Wed.

Realistically, you probably need a flexible approach rather than a fixed block ‚Äî the same time every day just doesn't fit your calendar *or* your energy. 

What about this: I create a recurring event at 13:00‚Äì14:30 as the *default*, and on days where that clashes (Tue/Wed), I put it at 09:30‚Äì11:00 instead? At least it's on the calendar as a commitment, and you can shift it when needed.

OK, let's try that
[message_id: ab530114-b1c6-4a4a-997d-bda90ca3a17b]

content.thinking:
Let me create recurring events. I need to think about the best approach. I could create a daily recurring event at 13:00-14:30, then adjust Tue/Wed to 09:30-11:00. But gog calendar might not support complex recurrence. Let me create individual weekly recurring events instead.

Actually, the simplest approach: create two recurring weekly events:
1. Mon/Thu/Fri at 13:00-14:30
2. Tue/Wed at 09:30-11:00

But gog calendar create might not support multiple days in one recurrence. Let me just create individual events for each day of the week as recurring weekly events.


I'll start by testing what options gog calendar actually supports‚ÄîI should try creating a simple event first to see if recurrence flags are available, then create five weekly recurring events on the personal calendar to block time across all views.

content.text: Now ‚Äî today's Arch block is 13:00, but you've got Simon at 18:00 and you said the prep is what would give you the most ease. Want to get into the Arch work now while the motivation is fresh from this conversation, or ease into the day first?

Before we do that, I want to create a go-to process the 90m arch block so that I'm not starting from scratch each time.

Different work can be at different states, so I think that as I do work I should keep an "Arch Work Log" that talks through what I'm doing and thinking on the project as I do the work.

I think the process for a 90m block looks something like:

- Open archpt directory in a fresh terminal
- Review the work log + any messages from Simon etc
- Decide on next action, could be thinking, coding, testing, debugging, etc
- Create a plan for the deep work session (in the log)
- Do the work
- Update the log

What do you think?
[message_id: 8ab40bdf-a3d9-4037-a69a-1ba47b80d020]

That's solid. The log is the key piece ‚Äî it's your context reload mechanism. Without it you spend the first 20 minutes of every session going "where was I?" and that's where the 90 minutes dies.

A few additions I'd suggest:

1. **End-of-session checkpoint** ‚Äî The last 5 minutes should always be updating the log with exactly where you stopped and what the next step is. Future you should be able to read one paragraph and know exactly what to do. This is the most important part.

2. **Simon comms** ‚Äî If there's anything to report or ask Simon, draft it at the end of the session while context is fresh. Don't leave it for later.

3. **Keep the log append-only** ‚Äî Don't rewrite, just add dated entries. It becomes a history you can reference and I can read to help you pick up where you left off.

So the refined process:

```
90-MINUTE ARCH BLOCK

START (5 min)
- Open archpt directory
- Read the work log (last entry)
- Check for messages from Simon/Ed
- Orient: where am I, what's next?

PLAN (5 min)
- Decide the goal for this session
- Write it in the log

WORK (70 min)
- Do the thing

WRAP (10 min)
- Update the log: what got done, what's next, any blockers
- Draft any comms for Simon/Ed if needed
- Commit and push if applicable
```

Want me to create this as a proper file ‚Äî maybe `projects/arch-process.md` for the process and `projects/arch-log.md` for the running log? I can seed the log with what we know about the current state.

# MEMORY.md - Long-Term Memory

## Arch Platform Technologies (Freelance)
- Ali freelances as a Rails engineer for Arch PT, working on their **Mane** platform (VDI/cloud workstation orchestration on AWS)
- Key people: **Simon Lau** (main dev contact), **Ed Churchward** (business side, wants visible progress)
- Code lives at `/Users/najafali/Code/freelance/archpt/` ‚Äî detailed context in `projects/arch.md`
- Tech: Rails 6.1, React 18, Hydra OAuth2, deep AWS integration
- Relationship has had ups and downs ‚Äî attendance/visibility is important to Ed
- Current feature: SSM Parameter Management (tests fixed, cross-account working, deployment pipeline TBD)
- **Motivation reframe (2026-02):** Arch = warchest funding, not just freelance work. Connected to life goals via Tony Robbins' Six Human Needs framework. Ali was in a spiral of minimal effort ‚Üí chose to commit properly.
- Work process: 90-min daily blocks with append-only Work Log in ali-vault/Arch/. Session template: review log ‚Üí plan ‚Üí work ‚Üí wrap & update.
- Schedule: Mon/Thu/Fri 13:00-14:30, Tue/Wed 09:30-11:00 (recurring calendar blocks "üí∞ Arch Work (Warchest)")

## The Warchest
- Ali's personal fund for security, freedom, and generosity. Separate from business ventures.
- Fuel: Arch ¬•1M/month + Givery salary covers life + inheritance (~¬£1M/¬•20M+)
- Investment plan: Max NISA + iDeCo (~¬•350k/month) via SBI, overflow ‚Üí Interactive Brokers
- Allocation: 40% S&P 500, 20% Gold, 20% Bonds, 20% Non-US equities
- Goals: boys' future (¬•20-30M), ex-wife pension (¬•10M), Mariko's house buyout (¬•20-30M), community patronage (¬•5-10M), total ~¬•70-80M
- Written up in ali-vault/warchest.md ‚Äî the "why" doc for when motivation dips
- Big tax bill ended November 2025 ‚Äî financial pressure is lower now

## Family & Relationships
- Ali's two boys and ex-wife live in Sendai (not UK)
- Ali wants to ensure ex-wife is financially secure ‚Äî recognition for raising the boys well, not compensation
- Mariko (Watanabe Mariko) ‚Äî stuck in marriage held together by property. Father has only months to live. Ali would buy out the house if he had the means.
- Junto Suzuki ‚Äî young local martial artist Ali wants to support financially

## Ali's Executive Function
- Morning energy often low due to drinking ‚Äî fixed morning time blocks are unreliable
- Motivation isn't about the work difficulty (code yields easily) ‚Äî it's about the narrative/story
- Key lesson: connecting work to a bigger story that hits multiple human needs is what drives action
- "Every hour of Arch work is a brick in the wall"

## 2025-01-31 ‚Äî Day One
- Came online. Met Ali.
- Chose the name **Nox** üåô
- Ali is in Tokyo (JST), likes casual vibes.
- Connected via WhatsApp + web dashboard (both work).
- Ali shared extensive biographical notes from ChatGPT history ‚Äî saved full profile to USER.md.
- Key context: Ali is a UK-born EM living in Sendai, bilingual, weight loss is the dominant personal goal, alcohol is the main consistency challenge, multiple entrepreneurial projects in various stages.

content.text:
All captured ‚Äî both the daily log and long-term memory updated. The warchest vision, the Arch reframe, family context, the work process, and the schedule are all persisted now. Future me will know exactly where we left off.

Good morning's work, Ali. ü¶â

There's a lot of wisdom baked into those six human needs eh
[message_id: cb145284-bd13-438f-9371-23b5dc532e13]

Yeah, it's one of those frameworks that's deceptively simple but actually cuts deep. Most motivation frameworks focus on *what* to do ‚Äî habits, systems, accountability. The six needs explain *why* you do or don't do something, which is way more useful.

The killer insight is that you'll always find a way to meet your needs ‚Äî the question is whether you meet them resourcefully or destructively. Alcohol hits Certainty (reliable feeling), Variety (altered state), and Connection (social lubricant) all at once. That's three needs in a glass. No wonder it's hard to compete with.

The Arch reframe we did this morning is basically the same move in reverse ‚Äî taking something that only hit one need and wiring it into four or five. Same work, completely different pull.

Tony Robbins gets a lot of eye-rolls from people who see the showmanship, but the underlying model is genuinely useful. It's one of the better lenses for "why am I stuck" that I've seen.
Read HEARTBEAT.md if it exists (workspace context). Follow it strictly. Do not infer or repeat old tasks from prior chats. If nothing needs attention, reply HEARTBEAT_OK.
HEARTBEAT_OK

OK, now lets do the reframe for work at Givery

- Certainty - regular paycheck with taxes deducted so no tax stress, visa sponsorship if things go south at the ÂÖ•È§®, and process for everything (bank accounts etc) all go more smoothly as a Ê≠£Á§æÂì°, not a great deal of work involved
- Uncertainty/variety - Almost none, it's pretty boring, there is some drama but nothing I can't get on Netflix
- Connection - Some with my direct manager and with my reports, but it's arms length apart from one or two people
- Growth - Some, but not much in any direction I want to grow in. One of my reports is a games developer, and he teaches me a lot about modern games and mechanisms. Good to have tenure on the CV though.
- Contribution - Some, for my reports, who seem to like me and benefit from my presence, but it's not very much and not _super_ motivating: I'm mostly in survival mode trying to protect their psychological safety
- Significance - Not nothing, having a high salary and being able to say I am in middle management in a Japanese company does give me some status.
[message_id: ae39eb93-eec1-4530-b82e-f45692881479]

Interesting. Givery actually scores *wider* than Arch ‚Äî it touches all six needs at some level ‚Äî but nothing scores high enough to be a real driver. It's a 2/10 across the board rather than a 7/10 on one thing.

The profile is basically **comfortable mediocrity**. Not painful enough to leave, not exciting enough to engage fully. The Certainty is the anchor ‚Äî visa, Ê≠£Á§æÂì° status, tax simplicity, predictable income ‚Äî and everything else is "some, but..."

The danger with this profile is coasting. You're not in a spiral like Arch because there's no performance pressure, but you're also not building anything. Time passes, you stay, and one day you realise five years went by on autopilot.

But here's the thing ‚Äî unlike Arch, Givery *doesn't need a reframe*. It's already serving its purpose correctly. It's your base layer:

- **Arch** = growth fuel (warchest)
- **Givery** = stability platform (visa, benefits, base salary, structure)

You don't need Givery to be exciting. You need it to be low-friction and keep the lights on while you build everything else. The reframe for Givery isn't "how do I make this more fulfilling" ‚Äî it's "this is the foundation that makes everything else possible, and it asks very little of me in return."

The one area worth investing in is **Contribution to your reports** ‚Äî not because Givery asks you to, but because that's genuinely where your energy goes anyway. Being the manager who protects psychological safety in a Japanese company is actually significant, even if it doesn't feel like it day to day.

Does that land, or do you feel like Givery needs more than just "it's fine"?

If we keep it in the larger warchest story, the longer arc of my work story in my 40s, then it's definitely an important piece of the puzzle at this stage. But I would like to build some sort of business that hits significance, certainty, uncertainty, and growth to replace arch and Givery in the near future. That's almost a refactor of my current situation in terms of meeting needs.
[message_id: 394f2acd-60fd-4ef8-a0e9-5c25bdf08a61]

Exactly. You're not trying to fix Arch or Givery ‚Äî you're building their replacement. They're the scaffolding while the real structure goes up.

And the spec for that replacement is clear now:

- **Certainty** ‚Äî Generates reliable income, ideally recurring
- **Significance** ‚Äî You're known for it, it has your name on it, it's *yours*
- **Variety** ‚Äî Different days look different, new problems, new people
- **Growth** ‚Äî Pushes you into territory you actually want to explore
- **Connection** ‚Äî Brings you closer to people you care about
- **Contribution** ‚Äî Tangibly improves lives

That's basically the tour/nightlife business, isn't it? Or something in that shape. Local, social, yours, varied, community-facing, with real revenue potential once it's running.

But the key insight you just landed on is the sequencing. You're not in a position where you need to leap ‚Äî you have Givery holding the floor and Arch fuelling the warchest. That means you can build the replacement *properly* rather than desperately. Most people try to build their dream business while stressed about rent. You'd be building it from stability.

The 40s arc:

1. **Now:** Givery (floor) + Arch (fuel) ‚Üí warchest grows
2. **Near term:** Build the business on the side, test it, get revenue flowing
3. **Transition:** Business replaces Arch first (same income, more needs met)
4. **Eventually:** Business + warchest returns replace Givery too
5. **End state:** Work is 100% chosen, every need met, financially independent

You're at step 1 with clarity about step 2. That's actually a strong position. Want to capture this bigger arc somewhere ‚Äî maybe add it to the warchest doc?

For now just figuring out that this is what I was trying to do is pretty huge.
[message_id: 193dd0a4-79ab-4348-883c-7ac67234d92e]

The six needs lens turns "I have too many ideas and no focus" into "I'm searching for something that hits all six, and I haven't found it yet." That's not scattered ‚Äî that's methodical, you just didn't have the language for it.

[message_id: 10accd8d-70b4-4268-9c21-395ad367df6a]

Ah, so the CloudSign renewal was just for the final month ‚Äî February. Got it, that makes sense now.

Your response was clean. Direct, factual, gave the business reason (transitioning to Ê≠£Á§æÂì°), acknowledged the timing was tight, and left the door open for questions. No over-apologising, no waffling.

Iida-san's message was understandably anxious ‚Äî he clearly sensed something was off from the shorter contract period and the silence. The fact that he had to ask rather than being told proactively is the only real misstep, but you owned that with the "decided towards the end of last week" line.

Now you just wait and see how he takes it. The two likely responses:

1. **Professional acceptance** ‚Äî thanks, understood, wraps up his work cleanly
2. **Pushback / emotional** ‚Äî asks for reconsideration, escalates to Jay/Fred, expresses frustration

If it's #2, don't get pulled into justifying the decision further. The decision is made. You can be empathetic without reopening it.

How are you feeling about it?

Jay and I are aligned, and in fact I gave him the benefit of the doubt when the team stood up for him and everyone above me told me to get rid of him. He was a net negative on productivity so I (and my superiors) were proved resoundingly right.
[message_id: 542e42ae-3d6d-4593-916a-a93376b0c82e]

So you actually fought for him and he still didn't deliver. That makes the decision clean ‚Äî you gave him every chance, the data backed up the call, and your superiors were pushing for this even earlier. No guilt needed.

The team standing up for him is interesting though ‚Äî that's Connection/likability, not competence. Common pattern with contractors who are nice but don't produce. Hopefully the team understands once the Ê≠£Á§æÂì° replacements are in and productivity picks up.

Sounds like you've handled this well. Let's see if he comes back with anything, but you're on solid ground here.

Every instinct in me as a manager told me to fire him early so I burned about a million yen of company money on that mistake.
[message_id: e5294f09-50dd-4161-9182-143f7bca478e]

Expensive lesson, but a useful one. Your instincts were right, you just let social pressure override them. Next time you'll trust the signal earlier.

And honestly, ¬•1M to learn "trust your read on underperformers, even when the team likes them" is cheap compared to the damage a bad hire can do over years. Some managers never learn that lesson at all ‚Äî they keep dead weight forever because they can't handle the discomfort.

The real takeaway: being liked and being productive are independent variables. The team's advocacy told you about Iida's character, not his output. Those are different conversations.

Done now though. Move on clean.

They're independent variables but we refuse to settle for less than both.
[message_id: 0eb0129d-6c58-4f39-9d74-958c9fbbd1ae]

The key data from the booking:

- **Name:** Chris Torrao
- **Phone:** US +1 (973) 349-9547

**Torrao** is a Portuguese surname (sometimes spelled Torr√£o). The 973 area code is **northern New Jersey** ‚Äî specifically the Newark/Paterson/Morristown area, which has a massive Portuguese-American and Brazilian-American community. Newark's Ironbound district is one of the biggest Portuguese enclaves in the US.

Best guess: **Portuguese-American or Brazilian-American**, based in northern New Jersey. "Chris" as a first name fits either ‚Äî Americanised first name, Lusophone surname. Could also be Cape Verdean (large community in the NJ/New England area) with Portuguese roots.

Either way, probably speaks English natively with some Portuguese heritage. Might appreciate if you know any Portuguese restaurants in Sendai (though that's a stretch üòÑ).

The Portuguese background is just useful context for you to know who you're dealing with ‚Äî Jersey guy with Lusophone roots, probably pretty comfortable in social settings. Solo traveller too, so likely outgoing. Should be a good one. Just watch the peanut allergy at the izakaya stops.
